name: Felbamate (Felbatol)
summary: An anticonvulsant used in severe epilepsy cases, particularly Lennox–Gastaut syndrome and refractory partial seizures.
description: Felbamate is an anticonvulsant that inhibits NMDA receptor activity and modulates GABA-A receptor responses. Due to its association with rare but serious adverse effects, such as aplastic anemia and hepatic failure, felbamate is reserved for severe, treatment-resistant epilepsy, including Lennox–Gastaut syndrome and refractory partial seizures.

sections.text: Blocks NMDA receptor-mediated excitatory neurotransmission and potentiates GABAergic inhibitory neurotransmission.

adult.partial_seizures: Initial: 1200 mg/day in 3–4 divided doses; increase by 600 mg/day every 1–2 weeks; maintenance: 2400–3600 mg/day

sections.pediatric: 15 mg/kg/day divided every 8 hours; increase gradually to 30–45 mg/kg/day

sections.text: Onset within days to weeks; duration of action approximately 6–8 hours.

sections.black_box: Risk of aplastic anemia and hepatic failure. Use only in severe epilepsy cases where benefits outweigh risks.
other: Discontinue immediately if liver dysfunction or bone marrow suppression occurs
Requires informed consent before initiation in some jurisdictions

items.risk: Decreased carbamazepine levels; increased carbamazepine epoxide levels

items: Liver function tests at baseline and regularly

sections.lactation: Unknown if excreted in human milk; use caution
sections.pediatrics: Approved for Lennox–Gastaut in children ≥2 years
sections.geriatrics: Monitor closely for hepatic and hematologic side effects

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over at least 1–2 weeks to avoid seizure recurrence.

items: Not a first-line antiepileptic due to severe adverse effect profile
May be life-changing for certain refractory epilepsy patients

seo.title: Felbamate (Felbatol): Anticonvulsant for Severe Epilepsy
seo.description: Felbamate (Felbatol) is an anticonvulsant reserved for severe, refractory epilepsy due to risks of aplastic anemia and hepatic failure.
